subject: Re: [junit] Adding a listener without using core?
msgSnippet: Hill, There s nothing super easy.  You can also add a listener from the RunNotifier passed to run(). We re looking at some similar issues.  Ideally, would you
messageBody:
Hill,

There's nothing super easy. You can also add a listener from the
RunNotifier passed to run().

We're looking at some similar issues. Ideally, would you have the
listener added by annotation?

David Saff

On Wed, Oct 8, 2008 at 12:21 PM, uly562000 <mike@...> wrote:
> Context: I am writing code that monitors the frequency, timing, and
> results of tests, and the code needs must run from eclipse, intellij,
> etc, relatively invisibly to the user.
>
> As far as I can tell, the only way to add a listener is to do it
> through the JUnitCore class. Unfortunately, I can't use the standard
> formula of running from main().
>
> Is there a way to add a listener from elsewhere in the dynamic object
> tree?
>
> I have a deliciously crude hack: Use RunsWith and a custom runner,
> then change the invokeMethod statement so that I can gather the info I
> need. It would be so much nicer if I could just add a listener, tho,
> because my hack would require me to extract all the info, which in
> fact a listener already gets all nicely packaged.
>
> Ideas?
> Hill
>
>
